thread.title: South Tyneside remains in hands of Labour as party increases majorities in Jarrow and South Shields

author: Chris Knight
title: South Tyneside remains in hands of Labour as party increases majorities in Jarrow and South Shields
text:
South Tyneside remains in hands of Labour as party increases majorities in Jarrow and South Shields Emma Lewell-Buck and Stephen Hepburn were both relected to South Shields and Jarrow respectively Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
South Tyneside remains red as Labour increased their grip on Jarrow and South Shields. 
Both Emma Lewell-Buck and Stephen Hepburn retained their places in Parliament and increased their majorities by thousands. 
Mr Hepburn, who has sat as Jarrow MP since 1997, earned 28,020 votes and boosted his majority to a massive 17,263 over his Conservative rival Robin Gwynne. There was a 0.77% swing blue to red. 
He said: “People are fed up with austerity. They know it’s unnecessary and is austerity to pay for billionaire tax cuts. 
“There’s no need for it anymore. 
“The main priority for Labour is to stop this agenda and get growth back into the economy to help young people who came out in droves get a better and more secure future.” Read More General Election 2017 North East results in full: How North East constituencies voted 
It was a similar story for Mrs Lewell-Buck in South Shields, who increased her majority to 14,508 after racking up 25,078 votes. It represented a 0.46% swing Conservative to Labour. 
The South Shields MP, who has faced three elections in four years due to the 2013 by-election, felt “overwhelmed” by the show of support. 
She added: “Theresa May went into this election thinking it would be all about Brexit. 
“The reality is when you drill down, people care more about bread and butter issues like the economy, schools, health and education - issues the Tories were not providing answers for.” 
Jarrow’s turnout was 66.36%, up 6% on 2015, while South Shields’ turnout was 64.26%, up 6.45%. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
